Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://thehackernews.com/2019/06/vlc-media-player-hacking.html

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: more hacks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as i said, basically no project is 100% immune to hacks

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: :sigh: this is going to get bad rep to opensource

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: why do you think it is limited to open source?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is all this automated build pipelines that many believe is some requirement that makes this such a big issue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and a lot of closed source has the automated build pipelines

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and it creates a "damned if you do, damned if you dont" situation, as when a new update is announced to fix a security problem, how many are deeply reviewing it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if you rebuild with the updated version, maybe you block the zeroday attack, or maybe you include some malware into the project

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i predict it wont be long before we get something that does both

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if you dont update, you are subject to the zeroday which is exploited at the user level, spam with enough clickbait to a malicious site to trigger the malware

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you do update, you build in the malware

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: alternative is to review every single update in detail, which will slow down the development process by a significant amount of time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only projects that write on top of very low level services with minimal external dependencies will be able to proceed without too much slowdown

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will indeed be a different world moving forward

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Hacks will escalate surely with more money and more projects involved

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: interesting to read this

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: even if one builds an app from zero ...with no open source libraries from scratch this could happen right? Unless you build it in a new programming language that nobody else has used but that's impossible because it won't be able to run in any normal PC.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: depends on the language, something that is built into the os like C, that has minimal external dependencies should be pretty safe

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: some of the new languages that autoupdate themselves all the time, not so much

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the hackers have to find just a single weakness, either technical or social

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am strongly considering going back to iguana, which is an almost fully self contained crypto codebase

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: since i wrote all of it from scratch, no worries of externally injected things

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: yeah I was thinking the same way...in this open source space the word "MONEY" and open source are not mixing well when the word "AutoUPDATE" and "GrandmaUSER" Exist

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: not only open source but also closed code that uses open source libraries

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: alright well at least there will be more money for programmers to make

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the cost of software development in crypto just doubled

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
if you only rely on libs that are shipped with the OS, you are pretty safe, since it is pretty hard to inject malicious code there
and there are a lot of libs and stuff shipped, so i don't think you will miss any functionality: https://www.debian.org/distrib/packages

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: @Hermes with most crypto apps you are dealing with multiple attack vectors. On the client and server side

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and user side

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not to mention the occasional protocol level issues, though those are pretty rare in bitcoin protocol coins

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Yeah. Scary stuff.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically dont put all your coins in one "place"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: distribute it out N ways, where N depends on how sad you would get if 1/N is lost

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the amount of work it is to maintain N different "places"

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Very true. We're currently designing 2 extra screens for Chameleon to stress the use of hardware wallets for substantial amounts. Hot wallets need to be thought of as spending wallets. Not longterm storage.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: I'm looking forward to adding ledger and trezor support for mobile. We're pushing to have it done by the end of the year.
